headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q4 2015 Discovery Communications, Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Whitney, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for rep
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q4 2015 Discovery Communications, Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Whitney, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Jackie Burka, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Discovery Communications' 2015 Fourth Quarter and Year-end Earnings Call. Joining me today are David Zaslav, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Andy Warren, our Chief Financial Officer.
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Discovery Communications' 2015 Fourth Quarter and Year-end Earnings Call. 
Joining me today are David Zaslav, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Andy Warren, our Chief Financial Officer. 
You should have received our earnings release, but if not, feel free to access it on our website at www.discoverycommunications.com. 
On today's call, we will begin with some opening comments from David and Andy, and then we will open up the call for your questions. [Operator Instructions] 
Before we start, I would like to remind you that comments today regarding the company's future business plans, prospects and financial performance are forward-looking statements that we make pursuant to the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are made based on management's current knowledge and assumptions about future events and may involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. In providing projections and other forward-looking statements, the company disclaims any intent or obligation to update them. 
For additional information on important factors that could affect these expectations, please see our Annual Report for the year ended December 31, 2015, and our subsequent filings made with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. 
And with that, I will turn the call over to David.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. 2015 was a year of solid growth at Discovery Communications. While it was a year that saw secular and economic challenges around the world, including strong currency headwinds, Discovery continued to b
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. 2015 was a year of solid growth at Discovery Communications. While it was a year that saw secular and economic challenges around the world, including strong currency headwinds, Discovery continued to benefit from our investments in content, brands and IP and our ability to execute in all types of macroeconomic environment. 
We experienced strong growth last year as we continue to execute on our key strategic objectives of growing global market share, launching new products and platforms and investing in more high-quality content and brands with universal appeal across our worldwide platform, including over the past couple of years, expanding and strengthening our content mix to focus in more on must-have categories that are more appealing to consumers, such as sports in Europe and kids in Latin America. 
In terms of volume share, our U.S. network delivery, again, outperformed the marketplace, led by Discovery Channel, Investigation Discovery, Science, Velocity and OWN. 
We continue to capture more viewers with our 11% portfolio share across cable. Most notably, Discovery Channel was the #1 nonsports cable network for men for the year. Had its most-watched year ever across all demos and grew total audience in the U.S. by 12% with women up high single digits year-over-year. 
Investigation Discovery continues to grow and prosper in ways the marketplace still hasn't given full value.  ID was the #1 network for women in total day in the full fourth quarter and #3 for the full year in the United States. 
For 4 years, 16 consecutive quarters in a row, ID has been the #1 network for length of tune in all of television in total day delivery.  Just an incredible performance. 
This performance also means that ID has significant opportunities to grow CPMs in recognition of this delivery strength. 
Last year, ID improved pricing, increased revenue and grew many new advertisers. The mystery and crime genre continues to pay and play remarkably well around the world and ID had its largest international audience ever in 2015, growing 20%. 
Going forward, we will continue to rollout ID to additional new markets, and we're just getting started. 
Our success was not limited to Discovery Channel and ID. OWN had its most-watched year in networks history of, its fourth consecutive year of double-digit prime growth in total viewers. 
Oprah is fully engaged and the channel together with a lot of original content and Tyler Perry and Oprah's Magic continues to grow in a meaningful way. 
And Velocity added nearly 5 million subscribers in the U.S. and have prime viewership among men up 24%. It is totally dominating the popular auto category. We're nearly 30% of the advertisers on Velocity are endemic and exclusive to this channel. 
Across Discovery's international portfolio, overall viewership was up more than 10% in 2015, driven most notably by the appeal of our female lifestyle brands such as TLC and Home & Health, and increasingly, our new Eurosport platform, which is growing aggressively. 
We also expanded the reach with several new channel launches, including multiple localized versions of Eurosport, a new free-to-air channels in Italy, Turkey, Finland and the Middle East. 
And recently, we launched Turbo Velocity in New Zealand. An increased distribution of Turbo Velocity 30% across Latin America in 2015. 
Our success across the diverse set of market illustrates our ability to grow in both emerging and established economies. Our increases in network delivery in the U.S. and abroad yielded strong add sale results. 
In the U.S., our sales team drove add revenues up an impressive 5% in the fourth quarter and 3% for the full year. 
Internationally, organic sales were up 12% for the fourth quarter and 11% for the year, driven by strength in Latin America and Southern Europe. 
This strength was due to our continued investment in diversifying our portfolio of brands and must-have content. 
Perhaps the best indicator of this was our groundbreaking agreement for the Olympic Games across Europe for the next decade. We have already started to monetize our Olympics investment with our first sublicensing deal with BBC announced earlier this month. The value of this deal meaningfully exceeded our business plan and ensures that in the U.K, Eurosport will be the only place where people will have access to all of the Olympic events for the next decade. 
During the year, Eurosport expanded its reach to now more than 150 million homes, up double digits since we took control and added more than 100 long-term sports rights deals, including key renewals like the Australian Open  and the U.S. Open. 
Many of our rights are exclusive and include reasonable and monitizeable price increases, which ensures that Eurosport will be profitable and will remain profitable.  These steps help drive double-digit increases in viewership on Eurosport across all of Europe. 
Discovery's portfolio of brand continues to also drive strong affiliate growth. Internationally, we redefined the value of our networks with strong affiliate renewals with carriers and markets, including Sweden, Singapore, France and Poland, driven by our growing audience share, investment in local sports rights and the Olympics. The strength of our portfolio was particularly evident in 2 recent negotiations with Telia in Sweden and Telenor in the Nordics, where we ended up pulling our signal and our drive to obtain strong sub-key increases. We are taking a much more aggressive stand to fight for the value of our content and to drive meaningfully higher sub fees. 
In both instances after we went dark, we ended up with strong renewals and a very favorable economic results. 
While being dark on Telenor for 11 days this month means we will yield a small negative impact on our first quarter results from the loss of advertising revenues for those 11 days. Our medium and long-term results will be much, much better and we will recognize significantly more value across our portfolio in that Northern European region. 
We are also starting to see additional financial upside as international distributors are increasingly looking for ways to differentiate their offerings to consumers with exclusive content and IT. This dynamic is a change in the marketplace and create a significant opportunity for us that really is all incremental growth since we own all of our own content. 
The diversity of our content portfolio enables us to be best positioned to create exclusive content and exclusive channel packages for many current and new distribution partners, and we are in conversations with many of distributors about this around the world. 
Some examples providing our partners with exclusive content are: A terrific deal we did with nc+ in Poland, which is part of the Canal Plus group; and 2 deals we did in the Middle East, one with OSN and another with BN, where we're able to give each distributor exclusive access to different packages of Discovery Networks. And in all 3 cases, we were able to yield significant incremental revenue. 
In 2015, Discovery made several senior A+ hires to focus on growing our revenues across all platforms. We hired a new Chief Commercial officer, Paul Guyardo, and his team is focused on a 3-prong multiplatform strategy to reach viewers across any and all devices and monetize this additional viewing. 
First in the U.S.,we're focused on reaching new viewers and strengthening the offerings of the MVPD ecosystem through TV Everywhere. 
In December, we launched Discovery GO, an authenticated TV Everywhere product in partnership with several U.S. distributors. 
While it is very early days, initial results are extremely encouraging as the number of users ad streams and ad dollars are all ahead of plan. 
Discovery GO also is helping us reach the younger audiences with almost half of its users in the 18 to 34 demo. 
Internationally, we are rolling out a kids TV Everywhere called product called Discovery Kids Play in Latin America, which launched with Sky in Brazil and last week with DISH in Mexico. 
Second, as we look to reach millennial audiences by bringing our linear brands to new platforms, we're also creating exciting new content for digital natives, including daily news and short form docs, audiences and advertisers are engaged in what Discovery Digital Networks are doing, and we see it because we have 350 million streams a month. 
Finally, we will continue to develop our direct-to-consumer products to complement our linear content and fuel the passion of our superfans. 
In Europe, we have been aggressively expanding our deep play in Eurosport player products, which both recorded double-digit subscriber growth for 2015. 
I am proud of all that Discovery achieved in 2015. While the world is changing, we are changing with it. And we ended 2016 with strong long-term deals locked in, our content compelling, our brands never stronger, all yielding real business momentum. 
Near term, ad trends are very healthy domestically, and we expect double-digit growth internationally and our global affiliate growth is locked in over the next several years is due to contracted price escalators. Our ownership of world-class content in IP at a lower cost per hour and in popular genres that play well all over the world gives us valuable optionality to monetize our content as media consumption continues to grow across all screen. This is what sets discovery apart, and we see more growth in the years to come. 
I will now turn the call over to Andy for details on our financial results.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. Despite continued secular challenges in the U.S. and currency headwinds internationally, we are pleased with the 2015 performance and optimistic about our continued ability to execute on our
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. 
Despite continued secular challenges in the U.S. and currency headwinds internationally, we are pleased with the 2015 performance and optimistic about our continued ability to execute on our stated strategic and financial objectives and the 3-year Investor Day guidance metrics going forward. 
For the full year 2015, all of our income statement metrics were in line with or exceeded our original guidance metrics. Excluding FX, Discovery's revenues increased 10%, adjusted OIBDA increased 4% and adjusted EPS was up 13%. 
On a reported basis, Discovery's total company revenues for the year increased 2%, adjusted OIBDA decreased 4% and adjusted EPS also decreased 4%. 
As expected, given that approximately half of our revenues are outside the U.S., the strengthening dollar was, again, a major headwind in 2015 as changes in currency rates, especially Latin American currencies and the euro, had a year-over-year negative impact of over $460 million or 8% on revenues and over $185 million or 8% negative impact in adjusted OIBDA and $0.30 or 17% negative above and below the line impact on adjusted EPS. 
On an organic basis for, or excluding the impact of foreign currency, Eurosport the SBS Radio sale and consolidation of Discovery Family, full year total company revenues were 6% and adjusted OIBDA grew 3% as we, again, demonstrated our ability to deliver consistently strong financial results even as we continue to invest in strengthening our global IP, platforms and brands. 
Full year net income available to Discovery Communications of $1 billion was down versus last year, driven by negative currency impacts on or above and below-the-line results, partially offset by the benefit of our lower effective tax rate. 
Our full year effective tax rate came down another 200 basis points to 33% as we remain laser-focused on lowering both our effective and cash tax rates by fully utilizing the increasingly international mix of our business. 
For the full year, free cash flow decreased 2% to $1.17 billion, primarily driven by timing of working capital, higher content spend and the negative impacts from currency, partially offset by lower cash taxes, long-term incentive payments and capital expenditures. 
Free cash flow came in just below our guidance, above low single digits due to foreign exchange as the ultimate year-over-year FX impact on adjusted OIBDA was higher-than-anticipated and there were additional negative currency impacts on working capital, especially in the last quarter of the year. 
Excluding the impact of currency, full year free cash flow was up approximately 8% versus 2014. 
Closing now on our fourth quarter results only. Reported total company revenues were down 2% and reported adjusted OIBDA was down 10%. Organic revenues, however, were up 8% and organic adjusted OIBDA was up 1% as expenses in the quarter grew faster than revenue, primarily due to higher content and marketing costs. 
Net income available to Discovery Communications decreased to $290 million, primarily due to foreign exchange and losses associated with the sale of businesses in 2015, partially offset by a decrease in restructuring costs and higher equity earnings. 
Fourth quarter adjusted EPS was $0.38 compared to $0.43 a year ago, while fourth quarter currency constant adjusted EPS was actually up 12%. 
Free cash flow increased an impressive 53% in the quarter to $598 million, primarily due to lower cash taxes and timing of working capital, partially offset by negative impact of foreign exchange. 
Moving now to the individual operating units. Despite continued concerns about domestic secular trends, our U.S. Networks' fourth quarter revenues grew a solid 6%, driven by 7% distribution and 5% advertising growth. 
U.S. distribution revenues were up 7%, consistent with 2015's previously reported organic quarterly growth rates. While total portfolio subs did decline by just over 1% year-over-year, we, again, benefited from the higher rates we garnered from our deals with NTTC, Cablevision, Sony and others at the end of 2014 and early 2015 as well as some contributions from our Hulu deal. 
On the advertising side, we are extremely pleased to report another quarter of mid-single digit growth with ad sales up 5%. 
As David mentioned, our ratings, again, outperformed the industry and this outperformance allowed us to benefit from robust scatter pricing and volume as well as stronger overall market demand. 
Looking ahead to 2016, given current ad market trends of stronger scatter pricing and our improving total impressions, we expect U.S. year-over-year ad sales growth in the first quarter to, again, be up mid-single digits. 
While we continue to see strong ad demand in pricing, we're still taking a more conservative view on our full year ad sales and expect growth trends to moderate in the future quarters, largely driven by the impact of the Olympics in the third quarter. 
Fourth quarter domestic adjusted OIBDA was at 1% as operating expenses were up 11%. Cost to revenues were 12% due to writing off certain Discovery and Animal Planet programming as our new creative management team focused on pivoting the networks towards more on brand content and SG&A was up 8% due to the increased marketing spend. 
For the full year 2015, total U.S. revenues and adjusted OIBDA were both up 6%, excluding the impact of consolidating Discovery Family, full year U.S. revenues were up 4%, for advertising up 2% and distribution revenues up 7%, while total cost were up 4%, leading to adjusted OIBDA growing 3%. 
Turning to the International segment. Our International Networks delivered another quarter of strong organic ad and distribution growth as we executed very well on our stated objectives of high single digit organic affiliate growth and low double-digit organic advertising growth for the fourth quarter and full year. 
As already mentioned, the flip side of having a large, growing international business is that currency remained a major headwind on reported results versus 2014. 
Foreign exchange reduced fourth quarter international revenue and adjusted OIBDA growth rates by 13% and 17%, respectively, and reduced full year revenue and adjusted OIBDA by 14% and 16%, respectively. 
Reported results also included Eurosport and the recently divested SBS Radio business. 
For comparability purposes, the following international commentary will refer to all organic results only, say exclude the impact of Eurosport, SBS Radio and foreign exchange. 
Fourth quarter international revenue was up 11%, led by 12% advertising growth and 8% distribution growth. Advertising, again, grew double digits in the fourth quarter, primarily due to higher pricing and ratings in Southern Europe, higher pricing in volume in Latin America as well as higher pricing in volume in Asia. Affiliate revenues had another robust quarter of solid growth, increasing 8%. 
For the full year, organic advertising revenues were up 11% and organic distribution revenues were up 7%. By the ad sales ban and rules change in Russia, we were able to deliver a very impressive growth rates to reflect the vitality of our international brands and business. 
Looking ahead, at our Investor Day, we stated that international advertising and affiliate revenues excluding currency would each growth in the high single digit range over the next 3 years. Given the current advertising strength in many of our markets, especially in Latin America and Southern Europe, we were still benefiting from share gains as well as pricing increases. We expect 2016 organic advertising to exclude the impact of SBS Radio as well as foreign exchange to continue to grow low double digits. Clearly, our international revenue momentum remains strong and intact. 
Turning to the cost side. Organic operating cost internationally were up 18% in the fourth quarter, driven by increased content and marketing expenses as well as higher personnel costs. Content expenses were higher, primarily due to writing off certain programming with changes in creative and regional leadership in the Nordics. 
Full year organic costs were up 11%. Adjusted OIBDA grew 1% in the fourth quarter and 5% for the full year. 
Eurosport standalone margin for the full year came in as expected at 7% as we invested in linear and digital sports rights to drive sustained, long-term value. 
As previously stated, we will no longer break out the results of Eurosport going forward as it will not significantly impact the comparability of DNS results in future periods. 
Now moving on to Education and Other segment. As expected, this division reported 0 adjusted OIBDA in the fourth quarter and a small operating loss for the year. Given our continuing strategic focus on producing and utilizing more content from our in-house OWN production studios, which has no margin associated with it and our continued investment in educations' digital textbooks to drive the long term value of the industry disrupting business, this segment will continue to operate around breakeven even though it's expected to grow revenues in 2016. 
Now taking a look at our overall company financial position. In the fourth quarter, we resumed our share buyback program, and we purchased $375 million of the common stock. 
During 2015, we brought back a total of $950 million worth of common and preferred shares and since inception of our buyback program in 2010, we have now repurchased over $6.6 billion of our stock, reducing our outstanding share count by over 33%. 
As we look ahead to 2016, our capital allocation priorities remain the same as we best position ourselves for the future. First, to invest in driving organic growth; second, to invest in strategic M&A, platforms and IP to have a strong return on investments; and third, to repurchase our stock. 
As we stated on previous calls, we are firmly committed to remaining an investment-grade rated company and are comfortable with our gross leverage ratio being in the 3.25 to 3.4 leverage range. And we will, therefore, likely raise additional debt in 2016. 
We still intend to be a very active buyer of our stock in 2016 as the IRR under purchasing our stock remains very compelling given our long-range plan free cash flow per share growth expectations. 
Given this, we expect to continue to allocate a substantial and growing amount of available capital shall repurchases in 2016 and future years. 
Now let's focus on our financial expectations going forward. As we first announced in our September Investor Day, we still expect our constant currency-adjusted EPS CAGR for 2015 to 2018 to grow at least in the low double-digit range. 
I also want to clarify that our expected free cash flow CAGR over the same 3-year period will be on a constant currency basis as we are firmly committing to real operating execution and performance versus uncontrollable foreign exchange movements, which could ultimately have a positive or negative impact on our cash flow results. We still expect this constant currency free cash flow CAGR to also at least in the low double-digit range. 
Looking specifically at 2016, constant currency-adjusted EPS and constant currency free cash flow are both expected to grow robustly in the low double-digit to low teens range. We also expect our full year effective tax rate to come down another 300 basis points to approximately 30%, one year ahead of our previous 30% effective tax rate commitment by 2017. 
Finally, we're, again, quantifying the expected foreign exchange impact on our 2016 results. 
At current spot rates, FX is expected to negatively impact revenues by approximately $185 million to $195 million and adjusted OIBDA by approximately $115 million to $125 million versus our 2015 reported results. 
While the strong dollar will likely to continue negatively impact our reported results in the near term, currency rates obviously fluctuate up and down, so FX rates do reverse direction as they always, overtime, revert back to the mean, this will have a very positive impact on our reported results. 
In closing, I want to emphasize that while we are cognizant of the current challenges in the media space, given our continued global audience share growth, global ad sales momentum, strong base cost productivity, declining effective tax rate and accelerating share repurchase expectations, I'm even more confident today than I was back at our Investor Day that we will certainly achieve or over deliver on our 3-year financial growth commitments. 
As an example, at our Investor Day, we forecasted at U.S. ad sales will be down low single digits in 2015 to 2018. Yet our current ad sales trend is at mid-single digits. Several other important trends, including U.S. ratings, U.S. sub-universe declines and our effective tax rate are also better today than we forecasted back at September. I really do feel great about our portfolio and financial momentum going into 2016. 
Thanks, again, for your time this morning. And David and I will now be happy to answer any questions you may have.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Doug Mitchelson with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Doug Mitchelson with UBS.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: One for David, one for Andy. So David, I was just hoping you could give us a more details on the company's digital efforts. And I guess, what I'm going is how are you balancing investing in any digital efforts versus delivering the bottom line results you
componenttext: One for David, one for Andy. So David, I was just hoping you could give us a more details on the company's digital efforts. And I guess, what I'm going is how are you balancing investing in any digital efforts versus delivering the bottom line results you guided to? And what should investors expect in 2016? Are there any milestones we should be looking forward to consider whether or not the digital offers continue to be successful? And for Andy, you talked about global affiliate growth luck over the next several years due to contracts. Certainly, there's increase in investor concerns in media in the U.S. around core cutting and skinny bundles impacts distribution affiliation. I think I was just hoping for clarification on the one comment you just made around the sub-trends are better than you thought they would be when you gave guidance back in October. Is that an improvement in the marketplace or just you were conservative guide the trends are unchanged? And just any reaffirmation that distribution consolidation, particularly the AT&T deal won't have any impact on trends as you look over that guidance period.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thank you, Doug. Okay, first, we're off to a very good start where we're attacking digital and I think in a very sensible way. We hired a new team, which is headed up by Paul Guyardo, and we have an attack team going hard at TV Everywhere, an
componenttext: Okay, great. Thank you, Doug. Okay, first, we're off to a very good start where we're attacking digital and I think in a very sensible way. We hired a new team, which is headed up by Paul Guyardo, and we have an attack team going hard at TV Everywhere, and we're starting to reap some real results. We're working very closely with Neil Smith in X1, which is a great platform, and we're finding our viewership there as increasing and it's really paying off for us and what we've said TV Everywhere is a great platform where we can monetize, and we are. I think we are the only company in the U.S. that has created our own aggregated app with D GO, which has all of our channels on it. And we've now been authenticated with commercials through a number of distributors. It's early days. Time Warner is just launching it as well. But the results early have been quite good. The demo is very young, the engagement is substantial, and we have a team that's really working on that and people are getting closer to our brands, and we're talking to our customers. So I think a really very positive turn in terms of TV Everywhere and our own authenticated app. Outside the U.S., it's really two things. Our Eurosport app is growing quite effectively. I don't -- we wont reach a million subs in 2016, but we do have a march to a million, and we're hoping to reach 1 million by '17. And 1 million at $8 a month will be an incremental $100 million. We have a lot more IP for Eurosport that we've been able to aggregated very reasonable price increases. Eurosport will stay profitable, and this could be meaningfully incremental. When you think about Europe being 700 million people, the ability to drive the direct-to-consumer business here could be quite substantial. And if we can get the 1 million, I think culturally, it can be a tipping point for us. We can get to 1 million, why can't get to 3 million, and we have the IP. And finally there's deep play, which we have in Northern Europe, and we're rolling out throughout Europe. And we've been doing that in our own. And we've been doing quite well. But we're learning more and more this is my own believe that there will be some our consolidation in a positive way. There's nothing stopping major distributors in Northern Europe, where we have 30% or 45% of market share to work with other major programmers. I think that will probably happen around the world over the next 4, 5 years. It's rather having a number of individual apps to come together, and we're having some of those discussions and I think to the extent that we do come together with others, that will even be more powerful. But when you look at the full portfolio of what we're doing direct-to-consumer and TV Everywhere, I think we're doing more, and we're doing it at lower cost than anyone because we own all of our content. And finally, we're not leaving the youngest demo out with our streaming business. We're not making money on that business today, but we're not losing money. But we have 350 million streams. And so when you think about that 350 million streams, and you think about Vice, and you think about Buzz Feed, that 350 million a month is growing, it's a millennial audience, they're spending time with us. And candidly, we haven't done a great job monetizing those streams. And the CPM's on them are quite good and now we have a whole team that is attacking the ability to engage with millennials and make money on those streams. So I think we're in a very good spot and over '16 and '17 I think you'll see some and a full results, and we'll keep you posted.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Doug, to get back to your question on U.S. affiliate, yes, back at Investor Day for the 3-year period, we kind of assumed that I think conservatively that the sub-decline would be about 2.5% a year. And if you look at in '15, we were down 1% 0 of our
componenttext: And Doug, to get back to your question on U.S. affiliate, yes, back at Investor Day for the 3-year period, we kind of assumed that I think conservatively that the sub-decline would be about 2.5% a year. And if you look at in '15, we were down 1% 0 of our portfolio. If you look at what the affiliates have reported in the last reports, clearly, the trends are better. So look, I think we were, arguably, conservative back in September and the recent trends are better than that. And then regarding your question on consolidation, look, as far as the deals with Charter and Time Warner and Cablevision, the impacts there should be de minimus given the rate structures. And regarding Direct TV and AT&T, they're both paying at their rates that we have in the past. And when that deals comes up, we'll have a sense of kind of how that will play out. But right now, the rate structure seems to be very much in line with what we had in the past.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Anthony DiClemente a with Nomura.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Anthony DiClemente a with Nomura.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: First for David. David, as we kind of settle into 2016 here and look back on last year a little bit, with Apple, we saw this issue of when ADQ and Apple sit down with the content providers and your peers, and they, the programmers, are dead set on keeping
componenttext: First for David. David, as we kind of settle into 2016 here and look back on last year a little bit, with Apple, we saw this issue of when ADQ and Apple sit down with the content providers and your peers, and they, the programmers, are dead set on keeping all of the networks in the bundle, whether it be a streaming bundle, the likes of which people thought Apple might launch, those networks would include sports. It just got to the point where the cost of the consumer would have been too high for expanded online streaming offering. Where do you think we are in that conversation? And from here, is there anything that could change? What kind of has to happen for the industry to get closer to seeing more over-the-top services with fewer core networks included in those services such that they're actually appealing to the customer? And then Andy, I just wondered, if you look at your deals with Go90, Hulu and Sony, can you quantify how much of those adding on a quarterly basis? Like how much do they contribute to affiliate fee growth in the fourth quarter and then in your 2016 guidance, maybe can help us with, I think, you said high single digit for overall U.S. affiliate fees, that's your long term and and then sounds like that's intact for '16. And then just clarify what's included in that for those 3 deals, that would be really helpful.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Anthony. Well, look, I think in '15, there was all this noise around skinny bundles. And I said before that the majority of programmers have contracts at least for the next several years that maybe there could be a little bit of that, but that the
componenttext: Thanks, Anthony. Well, look, I think in '15, there was all this noise around skinny bundles. And I said before that the majority of programmers have contracts at least for the next several years that maybe there could be a little bit of that, but that the ability to really start changing the way you offer services, it's going to be another cycle, which will be several years. Having said that, we're very well-positioned for that skinny bundles in 2 ways. One, we have 14 channels that represent 11% or 12% of the viewership, but we're only reaping about 6% of the cost. we're relatively inexpensive. So when Eddie was looking for channels, and we have the #1 channel for men with Discovery, the #1 channel for women with ID, and we have all these affinity networks, the top network with TLC and Science, you can pick up 14 channels for less than the cost of 1 regional sports network. So one, it's very efficient piece. Two is, if we needed to go to our top 8, we make 86% of our revenue and more than 90% of our EBITDA from our top 8 networks. And so if ever did happen here in the U.S, we would be well positioned. I don't believe it's -- and sitting down with the distributors themselves with all the talk of the skinny bundles, and as appealing as it seems, most consumers seem to want the big bundle. And I think probably the most encouraging thing is that cable seems to be -- the numbers have really turned around. As Andy said, we haven't really -- we've seen it, but we haven't seen the full effect of it because there's a few months gap between when they announced and when we actually get paid. But it's very encouraging that there seems to be a change in the universe dynamics. It's also, as you look at the U.S., I think our U.S. business now looks like a meaningful growth business. We have advertising market, much stronger than we expected. Our viewership is growing and the universe decline and the skinny bundles noise seems to dissipated to kind of a reality, which is not too much on skinny bundles and universe maybe charging around. And so, I think quite encouraging for the next couple of years. I'd like over-the-top to happen in a meaningful way because I think ultimately, we have really good services, our channels are on brand and they're reasonable. And we'll be one of the big recipients of that, but I think it's going to be a while.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Anthony to address your U.S. affiliate questions, without giving specific numbers, SVOD in 2015 and '16 will be less than 1% of total U.S. affiliate so it certainly is not a growth driver in '16 versus '15. Also to clarify, Sony actually is non-SVOD.
componenttext: And Anthony to address your U.S. affiliate questions, without giving specific numbers, SVOD in 2015 and '16 will be less than 1% of total U.S. affiliate so it certainly is not a growth driver in '16 versus '15. Also to clarify, Sony actually is non-SVOD. It's in the overall kind of -- yes, it's in the U.S. affiliate, but we haven't really categorized that as SVOD. And then your other question about high single digit, what we said in the past was the pricing clearly is accreting higher, and we've seen that now for a couple of years going, and we'll see it again in 2016. What we said that it would be high single digit predicated upon kind of a stable universe. And so we had some expectations about what the universe decline would look like. And so we'll not give any specifics 2016 affiliate guidance even though very clearly, the deals we've done and the deals that we anticipate doing will accrete price and continue to drive growth there.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess, maybe this is just a little bit redundant, but is your guidance contingent upon any specific renewal for 2016 specifically?
componenttext: Okay. I guess, maybe this is just a little bit redundant, but is your guidance contingent upon any specific renewal for 2016 specifically?

componenttext: Well, look, we're not going to talk, Anthony, specifically about any deals that we are coming up. We still have expectations of what those deals would look like. At this point, we have lot of confidence given the deals that we've done the last several years. Again, about 80% of our U.S. subs have been renewed in the last several years. So yes, we have an expectation. We're not going to say specifically what they are or how much of this. But again, the confidence is, the deals that we've done over the last 3 years.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andy, just on the guidance if you could help fill us in. I don't  know if you want to comment on FX growth expectations domestically and internationally just help us think about kind of margins for the year, you can obviously ex currency, that will be eas
componenttext: Andy, just on the guidance if you could help fill us in. I don't  know if you want to comment on FX growth expectations domestically and internationally just help us think about kind of margins for the year, you can obviously ex currency, that will be easier.and then maybe just to clarify from Anthony's question on affiliate revenues. Can we assume that the Comcast agreement will be represented in the first quarter results because I think that deal is signed last summer. I just want to see if you could comment there. And then David, I heard your comments on the Telenor situation was really interesting. You know better than anybody that there are big differences between Pan-European distribution and U.S. distribution dynamics, but how do you look at the increasing tension between programmers and distributors in Europe as you move forward? Do you view this as an opportunity maybe accelerate your business and maybe you're underpaid historically? Or do you think that's going a create more volatility in the results? What could you tell us since you're much closer to that than we are?

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andy. And so with Telenor and with Telia, we were able to get meaningful step ups in increases. Remember that Europe and Latin America are a little bit than the U.S. in that historically Latin America has been mostly no price increases. Your incre
componenttext: Thanks, Andy. And so with Telenor and with Telia, we were able to get meaningful step ups in increases. Remember that Europe and Latin America are a little bit than the U.S. in that historically Latin America has been mostly no price increases. Your increases came from sub growth. And Europe was working like that until 2 years ago. And so we started to drive that idea in the last 2 years, and we've been getting increases. But in the last 12 months, we've taken the position that we need much more substantial increases. And putting kids together with our channels in Latin America and sports together with our suite and free-to-air and IP and all of our content together in Europe has helped us get bigger increases. But in order to get it, we really need to stand up for the value of our content. So we had to pull our signals twice. So I think there's 2 buckets. One is, you're going to see us fighting for significant incremental affiliate revenue and between the Olympics and Eurosport and the strength of Discovery and the strength of our female portfolio around the world, we think that we can get that, and you'll start to see our affiliate line growing in a meaningful way over the next -- it's a long cycle over the next year, 2 years, 3 years just like we did here in the U.S. And we have some optimism that maybe we could even do meaningfully better than that because our IP, we think, is quite good. But we're going to have to fight for it. I think the reverberation of pulling those signals in Northern Europe has been valuable in the deals that we've done recently have been very, very favorable, that's one. Two, you bring up a point that is a new phenomenon, but it's all incremental to us. The idea that distributors in Europe are starting to compete more aggressively is a real helper to us. And what they're starting to do, which we didn't anticipate is, that whether you're a satellite, cable or phone player, for the first time over the last 12 months, they have felt that owning the pipe directly to the handset or to the home is not enough. The need to be commoditized that pipe by owning unique exclusive content. And so this is really a new idea here. So we sell our 10 channels and then we get a distributors coming to us saying, do you have other great IP, you could sell just to us that we could promote, that we have just as content in the market. So we have been able to do. We've done 4 of those deals in the last 6 months. None of those were in our plan 4 months ago, 5 months ago. It's all incremental to us, our channel is in language and I think if it continues, if you have the BT is fighting with the Sky, if you have in each market if you have this competitive dynamics, and we can raise our hand and say, we have kids IP, we have sports IP, we have excess drama and nonfiction IP, that, that could be a whole incremental vein of revenue process. And we're starting to see it. If it continues, we'll be able to break it up for you in the years to come, but it's a very positive. And so what we see internationally is double-digit growth even though it's basically been flatlining for the last couple of years, and that will continue. Advertising remains strong. We have this new vein of opportunity with these distributors wanting exclusive content and the Olympics is going to help us with that. And so, I think quite favorable. The big negative is currency. Our international business is really -- it's doing extremely well. The big issue is currency.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ben to answer your OpEx questions. I appreciate there's a lot of moving parts here were some write offs and onetime items in the fourth quarter. Let me just provide some clarity and perspective. For 2015 kind of apples-to-apples constant currency, SG&A to
componenttext: Ben to answer your OpEx questions. I appreciate there's a lot of moving parts here were some write offs and onetime items in the fourth quarter. Let me just provide some clarity and perspective. For 2015 kind of apples-to-apples constant currency, SG&A total for the company was up low single digits with content costs up low double as we invested in rich loss In discovery and sports, et cetera. As I look into 2016, we see constant currency OpEx, SG&A up, again, only low single digits with cost to revenue being up high singles. So total cost, I'll call it mid-single for 2016. Just again to clarify, the foreign exchange impact in '16, we're saying that for OIBDA will be about $115 million to $125 million. As David said, look, clearly, foreign exchange has been a very challenging element for us given our desirable and national portfolio. The good news I'll say in FX you look at some the movements of currency last year. Some of these markets really can't get any worse. You look at example Venezuela, we went from a 5 to 1 exchange rate at the beginning of '15 to a 200 to 1 at the end of '15. And so in some of these markets, we've kind of taken the full bun of the hit, we'll see what happens from here. But I think in terms of OIBDA being about $115 million to $125 million and then lastly, on Comcast, yes, the Comcast deal is effective January and that new deal will be in our first quarter reported results.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from Vasily Karasyov with CLSA.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about OWN. First, could you please speak in a little more detail about your rating trends there specifically advertising revenue growth and relative to maybe your U.S. Networks reported networks? And then, what's your view on the ownership
componenttext: I wanted to ask about OWN. First, could you please speak in a little more detail about your rating trends there specifically advertising revenue growth and relative to maybe your U.S. Networks reported networks? And then, what's your view on the ownership structure right now? Is it optimal? And do you expect that it will evolve at all and what would that depend on?

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks so much. OWN is doing very, very well. It's top 20 network for women, so #1 network for African-American women. On Tuesday nights, we're the #1 network for all women in cable. And the channel is on brand with some great content from Oprah. So
componenttext: Okay, thanks so much. OWN is doing very, very well. It's top 20 network for women, so #1 network for African-American women. On Tuesday nights, we're the #1 network for all women in cable. And the channel is on brand with some great content from Oprah. So we have happy audience that we're nourishing, that they're spending a lot of time with us. And Oprah is very engaged. We grew our audience double-digit. We have a very strong leadership team there with Eric and Sherry working very closely with Oprah. She works with them for many years of Harpo. So I think we're in a very strong trajectory. In terms of affiliate fees, more than 80% of the affiliate fees are locked with meaningful increases and the channel is almost 90 million homes. And so we took a channel that was in 75 million homes and had no sub fees. Four years ago, it's in almost 90 million homes. It's making a lot of money, it's a top network and Oprah has created a great success. The channel is owned 50-50. As we disclosed when we did the deal, Oprah has some stage puts that she can elect to take or not. The first election opportunity is this year and they're staged throughout the next 6 or 7 years. And we love the channel. If over time, the channel ends up -- we have an opportunity to own more of the channel, and it's only good thing for us. We're very confident in it. We think it is a great niche and some very strong IP. And over time, as our grows gross, we have an opportunity to consolidate it, that would be very favorable for us. But in the meantime, it's a 50-50 venture with Oprah having rights to put interest us overtime beginning this year and she's very happy with the venture. We're very happy with the venture, and it's quite a success story.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to put some financial metrics behind that. Look, again, the results for us continue to get better. We do, as I think everyone knows, all the free cash flow comes to us in the form of a loan payments. That amount in 2015 was $85 million, $20 million m
componenttext: Just to put some financial metrics behind that. Look, again, the results for us continue to get better. We do, as I think everyone knows, all the free cash flow comes to us in the form of a loan payments. That amount in 2015 was $85 million, $20 million more than it was in 2014. The loan has gone from over $500 million years ago to $380 million. We expect that loan to get fully repaid over the next several years. And look, the financial trends a very good for us as David said without consolidate today, so, while we talk about our free cash flow growth and how we're creating that important line, the cash flow growth of OWN is not included in that, but yet it's certainly part of our treasury and part of our overall capital availability. So the trend is very good financially for us as well.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Alexia Quadrani with JPMorgan.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, just following up in this exclusive custom packages you spoke about in international markets Oprah premiums. Can we assume they're accretive to the profitability just given the extent of cost to this exclusive content? And I guess, kind of potential
componenttext: Dave, just following up in this exclusive custom packages you spoke about in international markets Oprah premiums. Can we assume they're accretive to the profitability just given the extent of cost to this exclusive content? And I guess, kind of potentially come to the U.S. are not really realistic given sort of more distributors in market? Just a follow-up for Andy if I can on the domestic advertising outlook for 2016. I know in '15, you talked about reducing some advertising load. I just wonder if we can cycle through that for '16.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, for international, we've acquired all this content with assumption that we were going to use it on our lean your channels that we were going to use it on TV Everywhere, on VOD, direct-to-consumer. We have this huge library of content in kids an
componenttext: Yes. Look, for international, we've acquired all this content with assumption that we were going to use it on our lean your channels that we were going to use it on TV Everywhere, on VOD, direct-to-consumer. We have this huge library of content in kids and sports, in nonfiction and drama that we own. And so do deals that we've done is almost all incremental because we haven't bought any content to provide these exclusive packages. And so whether they come in the form of launching an additional 2 or 3 channels in the market in language or whether it comes in providing exclusive content, it's content that we already own, and so it's all incremental. I think it's less likely to happen here, and we will see how things develop. Right now, TV Everywhere is our #1 priority giving our content to the distributors. Here we are in the U.S., we're having high single digit affiliate growth, Universe is starting to hold its own and our viewership is growing. We have a very healthy U.S. business, and so I think a part of that is going back to our distributors and working with them on TV Everywhere, working with them on VOD, working with them on authenticated apps, which benefits both of us. And so, I think that we've started to tilt. We've got a long way to go, but we started to tilt in a very positive direction with TV Everywhere, which is a very attractive instrument versus kind of the blunt force instruments of some of the SVOD platforms that have no advertising, no branding and our kind of operating outside the existing infrastructure.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Alexia, just a couple of ad sales comments. But if you told me a year ago that we'll be having the ad sales performance today with fourth quarter up 5, the third quarter strong, some very good mid-single digit growth as we said going into the first qu
componenttext: And Alexia, just a couple of ad sales comments. But if you told me a year ago that we'll be having the ad sales performance today with fourth quarter up 5, the third quarter strong, some very good mid-single digit growth as we said going into the first quarter, I would have been thrilled. I mean, we're clearly the scatter market there, volume is strong, pricing is strong, far better than we had expected and clearly better than we thought back at our Investor Day. With regard to the ad load, look, today, we already have an add load that's less than the industry average. Yes, we have pulled back ad loads in some of our networks, which I think is one reason why our delivery continues to outpace the industry. And so all of our guidance that we've given and some of the first quarter numbers that we've had reflect the fact that some of our networks will pull back inventory.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe a related question, Andy. Thanks for the comments on the outside of the business. But you give us a better sense of how you're thinking about the Olympics impact? Meaning, is the assumption that it has may be a direct couple of hundred basis point i
componenttext: Maybe a related question, Andy. Thanks for the comments on the outside of the business. But you give us a better sense of how you're thinking about the Olympics impact? Meaning, is the assumption that it has may be a direct couple of hundred basis point impact on the quarter and then money may also get pulled into or pushed out of other quarters? And is it your sense of the dollars flowing to digital have decelerated? And if so, is it a measurement issue?

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I just want to hit 1 point on the Olympics. When we did Olympics, we said that the Olympics would be profitable. We completed our first deal with the BBC, which was very favorable. We created a kind of a partnership. We didn't -- we have the Olympic
componenttext: John, I just want to hit 1 point on the Olympics. When we did Olympics, we said that the Olympics would be profitable. We completed our first deal with the BBC, which was very favorable. We created a kind of a partnership. We didn't -- we have the Olympics fall across Europe from 18 through 24, except for in France and the U.K. where the IOC have early done deals in 18 and 20. As part of our BBC deal, we got back the rights of the Olympics in the U.K. in 18 and 20, where they'll have 1 free-to-air channel and 1 red button digital channel. But we'll be the only place to get all of the Olympics in the U.K. for the next decade. We were able to get pricing that was significantly more favorable than is in our plan, and it also allows us now to do a Pan-European feed of the Olympics from an advertising perspective also because we could reach almost all 700 million people. So I would say that from something that we felt in terms of modeling that would be profitable given the conversations that we're having across Europe, owning the Olympic IP, we feel confident that it will be meaningfully profitable over the decade, but also that it will be a big helper to us as we build our mobile strategy, as we build our direct-to-consumer strategy and as we look to drive affiliate revenue. Because all distribution now that we were doing short-term deals with, they want to go longer term to include the Olympics.

headline: Discovery Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to add a couple of comments there, John. With regard to the Olympic rights that we have, as David said, it will be cash flow positive over the 10 year window. They'll have a de minimis impact on our '16, '17 results. And the early activity that t
componenttext: And just to add a couple of comments there, John. With regard to the Olympic rights that we have, as David said, it will be cash flow positive over the 10 year window. They'll have a de minimis impact on our '16, '17 results. And the early activity that the team is delivering on is clearly better than what our expectations when we did the deal. With regard to the U.S. Olympics, just maybe a part of your question, yes, we do expect it to have an impact certainly on our total ad sales in the third quarter as obviously that's a large amount of ad sales to fill. And with regard to kind of the move to digital, look, clearly, what we're still seeing is the trend out of trends, out of radio, out of door into TV and into digital. And so when we think about the TV ad sales clearly doing better than people thought, 6, 12 months ago, I think it does come down to reach. I mean to look at raising extension, for example, we reached 31 million viewers, that kind of reach is unvaluable and very hard to achieve in digital. So those kind of shows and assets for us clearly drive a lot of ad sales volume and pricing. So I think we're still seeing some of the more secular trends into TV and digital with Olympic impacting really isolated for us only in the third quarter.
